realise that everytime they run away they deprive a gentleman of his
lawful property. Morning, gentlemen.
Morning5 madams.
Good morning. (THE CROWD NOISES HAVE STOPPED BY NOW)
Row let me see. Which of you gentlemen is which?
I am Mr. de Tocquevillej and this is Mr. de Beaumont.
Mr. Tocquevillage the little one; Mr. Beaumont®s the big one. Well, I
hope I can remember that. And you gentlemen are from France?
That is perfectly correct.
We have been sent to make a special study.
Well, you” 11 have to do it on an empty stomach, if you don*t step lively.
Why, it must be five past eight, if it9s a minute. The gong here goes
at eight o'clock, you know5 and I wouldnH answer for there being many
vittles on the board by quarter after.
Then we had better hurry.
Sit wherever you like. If there8s any left, there3s fish, ham, baaf,
boiled fowls, eggs, pigeons, pumpkin pies, lobsters, vegetables, tea,
coffee, cider, sangaree, and cherry brandy. (HER VOICE SL0WI1 FADES
BACK AS THE LIST CONTINUES, AND CROSS FADES AS WE MOVE INTO THE
DINING ROOM, WITH:
KNIVES. FORKS AND CROCKERY GOING HARD AT IT.
We can sit here. (BOTH SPEAK VERY QUIETLY TO EACH OTHER)
Beef?
Thank you. Potatoes?
